articles.author: Akshay Joshi
articles.description:
I‚Äôve started more things than I‚Äôve finished.



There‚Äôs a Marathi phrase that haunts me:
‚Äú‡§Ü‡§∞‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§∞‚Äù ‚Äî brave only at the beginning.
That‚Äôs been me.
Every few weeks, I would ignite a new initiative.
And then‚Ä¶
The energy would dip.
I wasn't lazy. I was just undisciplined.
start.
Why I Started Strong


Because beginnings are easy.
Starting made me feel in control.
So I jumped to the next thing, chasing clarity where none existed.
What It Cost Me



A backlog of 80% complete initiatives
Loss of credibility with my own team
Technical debt disguised as momentum
Incomplete loops in validation, delivery, and feedback
And most painfully ‚Äî a reputation for ‚Äúgetting things started‚Äù
But never enough for ‚Äúgetting things done.‚Äù
Code, Culture, and Closure


I prided myself on innovation. But what I needed was consistency.
closure.
Code went unchecked.
This isn‚Äôt just a workflow issue.
me issue.
What I‚Äôm Doing Now


I‚Äôve decided to break this cycle.
No new initiatives until old ones are closed.
No task is ‚Äúdone‚Äù until validated, tested, and documented.
No PR is merged unless reviewed ‚Äî fully, fearlessly.
Daily logs, closure reports, and personal audits.
Not for the team. For me. To remind myself:
Shipping > Starting. Always.
This post is not a motivational speech.
I am the bottleneck.
No more ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§∞.
Finish what I start.
articles.title: ‚Äú‡§Ü‡§∞‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§∞‚Äù: The Brutal Truth About Me

articles.author: davinceleecode
articles.description:
When an API is loading slowly, there could be multiple reasons behind it. Here‚Äôs a breakdown of common causes and what they mean:
‚öôÔ∏è 1. Client-Side Issues
üê¢ Slow internet connection (e.g., poor mobile data or Wi-Fi)
üï∞Ô∏è Blocking synchronous code on the frontend, like large loops or animations that freeze UI
üì¶ Rendering too much data at once (e.g., a huge React table without pagination or virtualization)
‚ùå No loading indicators, which can make users feel the app is slower even if it isn‚Äôt
üåê 2. Network Issues
High latency due to physical distance between client and server
Network congestion or packet loss slowing requests
Firewall or proxy issues blocking or delaying requests
üñ•Ô∏è 3. Server-Side Issues
Server overloaded and can‚Äôt handle many concurrent requests
Synchronous/blocking operations in business logic causing delays
Database slow queries or locks slowing down responses
Not using asynchronous processing where appropriate
üìà 4. Design and Architectural Factors
API not designed for scalability or optimized for quick responses
Missing or inefficient caching mechanisms
Too many unnecessary data payloads increasing transfer size
üì° 5. External Factors
Third-party services or APIs called inside your API causing delays
Geographic location mismatch causing longer data travel times
If you found this helpful, consider supporting my work at ‚òï Buy Me a Coffee.
articles.title: Understanding API Loading Delays: Common Causes

articles.author: ANIRUDDHA ADAK
articles.description:
In the fascinating world of computer vision, segmentation isn't just about cutting images into pieces‚Äîit's about giving meaning and structure to every single pixel. But not all segmentation is created equal. There are four primary types, each serving a distinct purpose and offering increasing levels of detail and understanding.
At its most fundamental level, Image Segmentation divides an image into logical groups of pixels based on criteria like color, texture, or intensity. Think of it as drawing boundaries around areas with shared characteristics.
Groups pixels into regions (e.g., "this blob is a tree").
Outputs contours (outlines) or masks (filled areas).
Uses pseudo-coloring to differentiate segments visually.
Isolate distinct pixel groupings without assigning semantic meaning.
Buildin‚Ä¶
articles.title: Decoding Image Segmentation: From Basic Pixels to Panoptic Perfection

articles.author: Akshay Joshi
articles.description:
‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt ship code. You ship decisions. And we made too many of them blindly.‚Äù
For over a decade, at DoozieSoft, we built. We delivered. We grew. But amidst the commits and deployments, one critical piece kept slipping through the cracks ‚Äî Validation.
Not validation of forms or user inputs ‚Äî we had those.
But the real validation loop:
What was tasked vs. what the developer understood

What was built vs. what the client wanted

What was tested vs. what was shipped

What was reviewed vs. what was merged



This silent fracture led to a systemic dysfunction:
Code was written without clarity, merged without critique, and shipped without accountability.
The Broken Loop


Tasks were often communicated ad hoc, over calls, or in fragments. Developers made assumptions. Testers raised flags. Fixes‚Ä¶
articles.title: The Invisible Gap That Cost Us 12 Years: Lessons in Software Quality from the Trenches

articles.description:
Exception handling in PHP has evolved significantly with PHP 8, giving developers powerful tools to manage errors more efficiently. If you're working with PHP, understanding how try-catch blocks work and how to handle exceptions correctly is essential for writing robust and maintainable code.
Exception handling is the process of managing errors or unexpected behavior in a program. In PHP, this is typically done using the try-catch construct. The try block contains code that might throw an exception, while the catch block handles the exception. With the latest updates in PHP 8, this process has become more streamlined and developer-friendly.
One of the key improvements in PHP 8 is its support for multi-catch blocks. This means you can now catch multiple exception types in a single catch cla‚Ä¶
articles.title: Mastering Exception Handling in PHP 8: A Deep Dive into try-catch Enhancements

Some of the same Democrats had held up the bill in early May when they withdrew support, citing corruption concerns over President Donald Trump‚Äôs cryptocurrency dealings.
The bill‚Äôs opponents hailed lawmakers‚Äô refusal to support it but were soon taken aback when the senators reversed their position. The lightly amended legislation contained no provisions regarding World Liberty Financial, the Trump family‚Äôs crypto venture.

Robinhood submitted a 42-page proposal to the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), calling for a national framework to regulate tokenized real-world assets (RWAs).
The brokerage is seeking to modernize financial infrastructure by making tokenized assets legally equivalent to their traditional counterparts and enabling compliant onchain settlement, Forbes reported on May 20.
In the proposal, Robinhood also revealed plans for creating the Real World Asset Exchange (RRE), a trading platform offering offchain trade matching and onchain settlement for efficiency and transparency.
Robinhood is advocating for uniform federal standards to replace the patchwork of state-level securities regulations that currently apply. The platform would also integrate Know Your Customer (KYC) and Anti-Mon‚Ä¶

Cryptocurrency exchange Kraken announced the launch of regulated derivatives trading on its platform under the European Union‚Äôs Markets in Financial Instruments Directive (MiFID II).
According to a May 20 announcement, Kraken‚Äôs perpetual and fixed maturity crypto futures contracts will be available for trading by retail and institutional customers in the European Economic Area (EEA). The announcement follows the exchange acquiring an MiFID license in early February through the acquisition of a Cypriot investment firm, approved by the Cyprus Securities and Exchange Commission.
Kraken‚Äôs head of exchange, Shannon Kurtas, said, ‚ÄúEurope is one of the fastest-growing regions for digital asset trading and investment, with some of the most sophisticated and demanding clients and institutions.‚Äù

India‚Äôs Supreme Court questioned the government‚Äôs lack of regulatory clarity on cryptocurrencies despite imposing taxes on digital assets like Bitcoin.
According to the Indian legal news outlet LawChakra, the country‚Äôs Supreme Court expressed concern over the increasing use of Bitcoin (BTC) and other cryptocurrencies, which remain largely unregulated.
‚ÄúThis is a whole parallel economy running with such coins, and it is a danger to the economy of the country,‚Äù Justice Surya Kant reportedly said during a recent hearing related to an ongoing investigation into a Bitcoin transaction.
Kant said that while the government has implemented crypto taxation, it has failed to regulate the space.
‚ÄúIf you can tax it at 30%, also please regulate it as you have recognised it by taxing it,‚Äù the judge said.‚Ä¶
